title: 110_s2687
content: The "Medicare Beneficiary Protection Act of 2008" may be cited as the Act. It establishes a Medicare plan complaint system. The "Medicare Beneficiary Protection Act of 2008" establishes a Medicare plan complaint system under Section 1808 of the Social Security Act. This system includes developing and maintaining a plan complaint system to collect and maintain information. The Medicare Beneficiary Protection Act of 2008 establishes a plan complaint system to collect, track, and improve the reporting process for plan complaints. The system must be in place within 6 months of enactment. A plan complaint is defined as a complaint received by the Secretary through various means. The Medicare Beneficiary Protection Act of 2008 establishes a plan complaint system for Medicare Advantage and Part D eligible individuals to report complaints regarding various aspects of their plans. The system must be accessible and easy to use, with criteria set by the Secretary. The Medicare Beneficiary Protection Act of 2008 establishes a plan complaint system for Medicare Advantage and Part D eligible individuals. The system must be easy to use and involve appropriate experts to assess complaints, trigger interventions, guide quality improvement, provide clear responses, and adhere to established timelines. The Medicare Beneficiary Protection Act of 2008 establishes a plan complaint system for Medicare Advantage and Part D eligible individuals. The system ensures quick resolution of emergency complaints, unbiased processes, public accountability, and standard data reporting requirements. The Secretary will establish reporting requirements and develop a model electronic complaint form for easy access on the Medicare.gov website. The Medicare Beneficiary Protection Act of 2008 establishes a plan complaint system for Medicare Advantage and Part D eligible individuals. Complaints must be logged into the system, include casework notations, and be overseen by the Medicare Beneficiary Ombudsman. Funding is authorized for carrying out the provisions, and ongoing study reports will be conducted by the Secretary. The Medicare Beneficiary Ombudsman will conduct an ongoing study of the plan complaint system, analyzing complaints, geographic variations, response timeliness, and resolution. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit quarterly reports to Congress on the study of the plan complaint system, along with recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Inspector General will evaluate the system and submit a report to Congress with recommendations within one year of implementation. The Inspector General will provide recommendations for legislation and administrative actions as deemed appropriate. Requirement for non-network Medicare Advantage private fee-for-service plans to disclose providers that refuse to accept enrollees in the plan. The amendment requires Medicare Advantage private fee-for-service plans to disclose providers who have refused to accept enrollees in the plan. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect 90 days after the enactment of this Act. PROHIBITION ON PROVIDING CERTAIN INDUCEMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS ON MARKETING PRACTICES FOR MA PLANS AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG PLANS. The Medicare Advantage Program is amended to prohibit certain marketing practices, such as telemarketing and cross-selling of non-Medicare products. The Medicare Advantage Program prohibits certain marketing practices, including telemarketing and cross-selling of non-Medicare products. This prohibition also extends to the Medicare Prescription Drug Program. The amendments made by this section regarding marketing practices under section 1851(h)(4)(C) will apply to PDP sponsors and prescription drug plans similar to how they apply to Medicare Advantage organizations and plans. The effective date for these amendments will be 90 days after the enactment of the Act. Enrollment improvements under Medicare Parts C and D will be implemented following amendments to marketing practices, with the effective date set 90 days after the Act's enactment. The Special Election Period during the first 60 days of enrollment in a new plan is amended under Section 1851(e)(4) of the Social Security Act. The effective date for these amendments is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is an extension of the Annual, Coordinated Election Period under Section 1851(e)(3)(B)(iv) of the Social Security Act. The Special Election Period within the first 60 days of enrolling in a new plan is modified under Section 1851(e)(4) of the Social Security Act, with an effective date 90 days after the Act's enactment. Furthermore, there is an extension of the Annual, Coordinated Election Period under Section 1851(e)(3)(B)(iv) of the Social Security Act, with an amendment changing the start date to October 1. Additionally, coordination under Parts C and D for the Continuous Open Enrollment and Disenrollment Period for the first 3 months of the year is adjusted under Section 1860D-1(b)(1)(B)(iii) of the Social Security Act, effective January 1, 2009.
